dc:description:
Radial spoke head component 1(*RSPH1*) gene was first reported in relation to autosomal recessive Primary Ciliary Dyskinesia in 2013 (Kott E et al., PMID: 23993197).

Mutations in *RSPH1* gene were shown to cause PCD with a higher nasal nitric oxide and a milder clinical disease characterised by a delayed onset of pulmonary symptoms and the maintenance of better lung function when compared with PCD patients carrying mutations in other genes (PMID: 24568568 and PMID: 25473808). Absence of laterality defects is observed in all patients reported which coincides with a defect in the radial spokes linking each peripheral microtubule doublet to the two central microtubules in 9+2 cilia (PMID: 23993197). Infertility or subfertility is also reported in male and female patients (PMIDs: 24568568 and 23993197).
 
6 (nonsense, splice site, and missense) variants that have been reported in 6 probands in 3 publications (PMIDs: 23993197, 24518672, and 24568568) are included in the curation. More evidence is available in the literature, but the maximum score for genetic evidence (12 pts.) has been reached. The mechanism of pathogenicity appears to be biallelic loss of function.
 
Experimental evidence supporting this gene-disease association includes expression, structural and functional alteration in patient cells, and non-human model organism evidence. Biased RSPH1 expression in PCD relevant tissues (testis, lung, and fallopian tube) has been detected (PMID: 24309898). Cryo-electron tomography revealed a variety of CPC abnormalities in *RSPH1*-mutant cilia (apparently normal 9+2 microtubule arrangement, with one of the CPC microtubules missing (9+1), with the entire CPC missing (9+0), with the CPC replaced by one DMT ((8+1) +0), or with a doubled CPC with 4 singlet microtubules (9+4) (PMID: 25473808). Cilia from *RSPH1*-mutant individuals showed rotational movement, similar to that of nodal (9 + 0) cilia, compared to a mostly planar (back and forth) motion in healthy cilia (PMID: 24568568). In Chlamydomonas, Yang et al., 2006 (PMID: 16507594) identified RSP1(the ortholog of RSPH1) from isolated radial spokes by using mass spectrometric methods. Rsph1-/- mice showed various ciliary abnormalities with significantly reduced CBF.  The mutant animals also developed various degrees of hydrocephalus, similar to other mouse models of PCD (PMID: 30896965). 
  
In summary, *RSPH1* is definitively associated with autosomal recessive Primary Ciliary Dyskinesia 24. This has been repeatedly demonstrated in both the research and clinical diagnostic settings and has been upheld over time.This classification was approved by the ClinGen Motile Ciliopathy GCEP on June 7th, 2022 (SOP Version 8).

evidence.dc:description: the c.275-2A>C mutation, located upstream of the fourth exon, leads to the skipping of exons 4 and 5 and to a premature stop codon (p.Gly92Alafs*10). The variant has been repeatedly identified in homozygous status in 9 PCD patients and in compound heterozygosity in other 4 PCD patients (PMID: 24568568)
the c.275-2A>C mutation, located upstream of the fourth exon, leads to the skipping of exons 4 and 5 and to a premature stop codon (p.Gly92Alafs*10).

The c.727+5G>A mutation, involving the splice site downstream of the seventh exon, results in the incorporation of the first two intronic nucleotides in the spliced transcripts, leading to a premature stop codon (p.Ala244Valfs*22).

Total RNA from airway cells of the individual harboring the variation was isolated and RSPH1 transcripts was analysed after RT- PCR amplification. Results confirmed abnormal transcript incorporating two intronic nucleotides in the spliced transcripts.

evidence.rdfs:label: Kott_2013_DCP1057
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
lobectomy, rhinosinusitis, otitis, subfertility, Abnormal Cilia by (TEM) (23%). 
Patient also showed abnormal HSVM Parameters as follows; CBF 9.2 +_ 3.3(Hz),  Angle (53+_25), Distance Traveled 46.4 +_ 23 (mm/sec)

evidence.dc:description: the c.85G>T variation is a premature stop codon leading to a severely truncated protein lacking 90% of the protein, including all MORN repeats, or to the absence of production of the protein through activation of the nonsense-mediated-mRNA-decay pathway
Absence of RSPH1 protein from the cilia of the affected individual detected by IF

The apparently synonymous c.366G>A (p.=) transition involves the first base of the fifth exon; it could, therefore, affect splicing. Two transcripts were coamplified (Figure S3A): the minor molecular species, which harbors the G>A transition, is the result of normal splicing; the other molecular species lacks the fifth exon, leading to a premature stop codon in exon 6 (p.Arg122Serfs*22) (Figure S3B).
Absence of RSPH1 protein from the cilia of the affected individual detected by IF.

The  mutation c.275–2A>C disrupts a splice acceptor and has an experimental evidence of aberrant transcript. Highest frequency for European non Finnish population is 0.0006736 (gnomAD v.2.2.1). We Downscored for homozygosity.

Qualitative reverse-transcriptase polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) analysis using primers specific for exons 2 and 9 revealed a single major product of the expected size (930 bp) in RNA prepared from normal airway epithelia (Figure 2A). In contrast, RNA from the subject homozygous for the c.275–2A>C mutation produced primarily two shorter transcripts and several minor transcripts. One shorter
(631 bp) transcript was caused by an out-of-frame deletion of exons 4–6 (r.275–573del [p.Glu93Lysfs*24]) and another shorter (731 bp) transcript was caused by an out-of-frame deletion of exons 4–5 (r.275_501del [p.Gly92Alafs*10]), both leading to premature termination signals (Figure 1).

The c.85G>T variant leads to a premature stop codon at position 29 (p.Glu29*). The variant is expected to result in a severely truncated protein lacking 90% of the protein, including all MORN repeats, or to the absence of production of the protein through activation of the nonsense-mediated-mRNA-decay pathway. Highest allele frequency is reported in Latin/ admixed American at 0.0005645 (gnomAD v2.1.1). The score was reduced to 1 for homozygosity and consanguinity.

The c.85G>T variant leads to a premature stop codon at position 29 (p.Glu29*). The variant is expected to result in a severely truncated protein lacking 90% of the protein, including all MORN repeats, or to the absence of production of the protein through activation of the nonsense-mediated-mRNA-decay pathway. The publication reported 1 other proband carries the variant in homozygous state (DCP775), and three compound heterozygous probands (DCP876, DCP729, and DCP1064).

evidence.rdfs:label: Kott_2013_DCP940
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Subfertility, otitis, a very marked ultrastructural phenotype in which 60% of cilia showed CC defects (Figure 1 and Table 1) and total ciliary immotility in ciliated cells obtained by airway brushing

evidence.dc:description: a splice-site change c.275-2A>C affecting one of the 100% conserved exon 4 splice acceptor bases. Absence of RSPH1 protein is detected by IF in the individual carrying the mutation. Also, segregation is consistent with autosomal recessive inheritance and compound herterozygosity.
Absence of RSPH1 protein is detected by IF in the individual carrying the mutation

This sequence change creates a premature translational stop signal (p.Trp94*) in the RSPH1 gene. It is expected to result in an absent or disrupted protein product. Absence of RSPH1 protein is confirmed by IF in the proband carrying the mutation compared to control. Also, segregation is consistent with autosomal recessive inheritance and compound herterozygosity.
Absence of RSPH1 protein is detected by IF in the proband carrying the mutation compared to control.

evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Nasal nitric oxide was greatly reduced, measuring 50 and 79 ppb in independent tests

the expected deleterious consequences of the c.85G>T variation at the protein level (i.e., premature stop codon leading to a severely truncated protein lacking 90% of the protein, including all MORN repeats, or to the absence of production of the protein through activa- tion of the nonsense-mediated-mRNA-decay pathway

The p.Gly103Asp (c.308G>A) missense variation, replaces a hydrophobic amino acid with a charged hydrophilic acidic amino acid, involves a residue that is invariant throughout evolution and that is part of the MORN consensus. No experimental evidence regarding mRNA or protein absence in the proband carrying the variant.

The p.Gly103Asp (c.308G>A) missense variation, which replaces a hydrophobic amino acid with a charged hydrophilic acidic amino acid, involves a residue that is invariant throughout evolution and that is part of the MORN consensus

evidence.rdfs:label: Kott_2013_DCP729
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: lobectomy, rhinosinusitis, otitis, subfertility, NO 80nl/min, Abnormal cilia by TEM 22%

evidence.dc:description: PCD in human results from structural and/or functional defects of the ciliary epithelium. Here, the experiment illustrates structural defects by TEM and functional defects by detecting abnormal ciliary movement by HSVM and decreased rate of mucociliary clearance in Rsph1-/- animals.
evidence.rdfs:label: Rsph1-/- mice develop a PCD phenotype

evidence.dc:description: Defective ciliary function due to the evident abnormal motility explains the recurrent respiratory infection phenotype in the RSPH1 mutant patients as well as the subfertility phenotype attributed to defective flagellar motion of the patients sperm.

Analysis of high speed video recordings in slow motion revealed that the cilia on three individual cells from each of the children affected with primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD) (#1370 [III-1] and #1371 [III-2]) moved in a clockwise circle when viewed from above compared to beat in a mostly planar (back and forth) direction in the unaffected mother. When viewed from above, the cilia of affected siblings exhibited rotational (clockwise) movement, similar to the rotational movement of nodal (9 + 0) cilia.
evidence.rdfs:label: Mutations in RSPH1 result in a circular wave form

evidence.dc:description: The experiment presented the native 3D structures of normal and PCD- causing RSPH1-mutant human respiratory cilia, revealing the resulting defects in radial spokes, and uncovering a mechanism for the milder RSPH1-PCD-phenotype.

The cryo-tomograms revealed a variety of CPC abnormalities in a subset of RSPH1 mutant cilia. This was consistent with previous studies of PCD caused by mutations in putative RS head proteins, which revealed a subset of cilia that lacked the CPC (9+0 axoneme) or had one of the nine DMTs translocated to the centre of the axoneme ((8+1)+0).  PCD cilia with an apparently normal 9+2 microtubule arrangement (Fig. 5d), with one of the CPC microtubules missing (9+1; Fig. 5e), with the entire CPC missing (9+0; Fig. 5g), with the CPC replaced by one DMT ((8+1)+0; Fig. 5h), or with a doubled CPC with 4 singlet microtubules (9+4; Fig. 5f) were detected.
evidence.rdfs:label: Cryo-electron tomography reveals RSPH1-/- ciliary defects

evidence.dc:description: Expression of RSPH1 in testis and fallopian tubes is consistent with the subfertility phenotype detected in RSPH1 mutant PCD patients. The disease is characterized by recurrent respiratory infection resulted from defective mucociliary clearance which is also consistent with RSPH1 expression in ciliated epithelial cells of the lung.

Bulk tissue gene expression for RSPH1 revealed biased expression in testis , lung, and fallopian tube. Moreover,  Single cell snRNA-seq pilot detected RSPH1 in epithelial ciliated cells of the lung in more than 40% of the sample.
evidence.rdfs:label: Analysis of the human tissue-specific expression of RSPH1

evidence.dc:description:
The experiment confirms aberrant RSPH1 gene expression and absence of RSPH1 protein in PCD patients whereas a clear signal was present in lysates of normal differentiated
(ciliated) cultures, in agreement with the RNA data . A strong signal for RSPH1 was also observed in detergent isolated axonemes, demonstrating that the RSPH1 protein is an integral part of the ciliary axoneme.

Reverse-transcriptase polymerase chain reaction of the control sample resulted in a single, full-length product of approximately 930 bp, whereas the c.275–2A>C mutation resulted in predominantly two smaller products of approximately 650 and 750 bp, along with multiple other aberrantly spliced products were detected in RSPH1 mutant cells.
Western blot analysis has also confirmed absence of RSPH1 signal compared to normal control cells
evidence.rdfs:label: RSPH1 expression in PCD patient cells

evidence.dc:description:
To identify the previously unknown RSPs, spoke proteins from 2D gels of isolated axonemes or 20S radial spokes was purified. The excised gel spots for each protein were subjected to tryptic digestion and the resulting peptides were analyzed by matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionisation-time of flight mass spectrometry (MALDI-TOF MS). The MS and MS/MS data were used to search C. reinhardtii genomic and EST databases to identify nucleotide sequences encoding the peptides. RSPs 1, 5, 7, 8, 9, 10, 11, 12, 14 and 17 were identified.

To confirm that the MS analysis identified the correct proteins, Western blot analyses using Antibodies previously shown specifically to recognize natural RSP1 and RSP5 identified bacterially expressed recombinant RSP1 and RSP5, respectively.

The experiment also revealed that C. reinhardtii RSP1 is most similar to Homo sapiens meichroacidin, which is expressed primarily in the testis ; much of this similarity is a result of MORN repeats in both proteins.
evidence.rdfs:label: Radial spoke proteins of Chlamydomonas flagella
